General course objectives:
General course objectives
The course aims at providing methods and tools for the analysis, designing and evaluation of autonomy for robotic and high-automation solutions. The course offers a perspective into what makes robotic behavior autonomous and how autonomy is implemented in real world scenarios. Additionally, the course exposes the students to the technologies needed to build and implement autonomy for complex robotic systems.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Integrate the building blocks of robot operation, situational awareness, and robot introspection using ROS
Explain what autonomy is in a robotics context
Design and implement a behavioral system for robots operating in unknown environments
Describe mission planning, fault detection, environment changes, and re-planning
Interpret high-level mission goals to autonomous system architectures
Formulate and convert high-level mission goals to quantifiable objective functions
Explain the different steps in mobile robot localization and implement the related algorithms
Suggest and implement algorithms for robot situational awareness using multi-modal sensing
Content: Introduction to the robotic framework ROS; Motion and behavioral planning; Mission planning, mission execution and re-planning; Robot simulation; Situational awareness; Fault detection, robot introspection, sensor degradation and redundancy; Control architectures; Robot AI
